awd_titl_txt: Collaboration Of Midwest Professionals for Logistics Engineering Technology Education Project
awd_abstract_narration:
The supply chain, or logistics, industry continues to grow in the Midwest region of the United States. Jobs in this industry are also becoming more dependent on technologies such as predictive analytics, artificial intelligence, and robotics. Nearly 15,000 transportation and warehousing businesses are located across the cities of Columbus, Ohio; Dayton, Ohio; and Chicago, Illinois. The ongoing growth helps support and strengthen the logistics industry in this regional economy. As a result, there is an increasing need for logistics engineering technicians in the region. In this project, a grouping of community colleges who are leaders in the logistics field in this Midwest region will be formed. The project will be led by Columbus State Community College, Oakton Community College, and Sinclair Community College. It will seek to build career pathways in logistics engineering technology for students, encourage more students to complete degrees in this field, develop faculty experience on the latest technologies, and improve the technical skills of graduates. The goal will be to provide highly-skilled logistics engineering technicians to support the regional and national needs of the supply chain sector. 

The project will aim to improve technician education to support the increasingly complex technology needs of the supply chain sector while connecting graduates to employment opportunities in a variety of logistics industries. This project will work with employers, industry experts, and colleges to establish an innovation network. The network of partners will identify and create educational resources for emerging skills and technologies within the sector. The existing logistics curriculum at Columbus State Community College combines technology applications with engineering systems and integrates them with supply chain operations. This curriculum will be enhanced to integrate new topics in data-driven analytics and networking systems. The adapted curriculum will also be implemented and tested at the partnering institutions. The network infrastructure will inform and regularly evaluate efforts in curriculum and career pathway development; in providing professional development material and trainings for high school and college faculty; and on the use of prior learning assessments for adult and returning learners, particularly veterans and recent graduates in need of new skills for the ever-changing logistics job market. Results will be widely disseminated through an interactive project website, through publications, and at regional and national conferences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Columbus State Community College in Columbus, OH was awarded funding from the National Science Foundation in October 2018 to work with Oakton Community College in Des Plaines, IL and Sinclair Community College of Dayton, OH to expand pathways for next-generation logistics engineering technicians with the knowledge and skills to meet the increasingly complex technology needs of the supply chain sector. In addition to this consortium, the Collaboration of Midwest Professionals for Logistics Engineering Technology Education (COMPLETE) Project included input from several industry representatives across the Midwest and outreach to regional high school partners.

The COMPLETE project has integrated technology applications with engineering systems and how these technologies are integrated into supply chain operations including warehousing, transportation, and procurement operations. The project sought to achieve its outcome of developing more technicians with the knowledge and skills needed by the supply chain sector through the following four objectives.

  1. To expand on current logistics engineering technology curricula and establish a replication framework.
  2. To develop an innovation network that focuses on LET emerging technologies in logistics.
  3. To lead a professional development initiative for high school and college faculty about LET programming and careers.
  4. To create a best practices protocol for returning learner outreach and use of prior learning assessment.

The Amatrol Skill Boss Trainer has been incorporated in some way into the curricular changes at each institution.   This system was designed to teach and assess 100 hands-on skills that technicians need in supply chain automation, including equipment maintenance and equipment repair to help students earn the Manufacturing Skill Standard Council's Certified Technician - Supply Chain Automation certifications. 

Columbus State incorporated knowledge and skills related to Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) into their curriculum. The goal of ERP is the efficient integration and management of core business processes with an integrated system. The project team updated the existing course, Information Technology in Logistics, with a focus on ERP systems and functionality which will provide logistics engineering technology students with knowledge and skills that are more in-line with the work they will be performing in their roles.

Oakton purchased Programmable Logic Control trainers for teaching and troubleshooting Allen Bradley microprocessors. The trainers are being used in a new Motors and Control course as well as the existing Programmable Logic Controls course. Oakton also made curricular changes to better ensure that students are gaining the in-demand data analytics knowledge and skills by including a new course in Oakton's Computer Information Systems program on Data Visualization.

Sinclair developed a new AAS degree titled Internet of Things Cyber Technician (IoTCT). The degree provides students with a strong background in the basic concepts and in-depth study of advanced topics which will prepare graduates with the skills necessary to enter careers in installation, operation, application, maintenance, and repair of existing computer systems and associated networks. The hands-on learning will provide students with opportunities to put the Internet-of-Things and Industrial Internet-of-Things technologies and programming concepts into practice.  

Project team members from Columbus State and The Ohio State Community College's Fisher College of Business worked together to create O-SCAN, a professional network that is facilitating the collaboration and sharing of ideas between industry and higher education to promote the value of supply chain education and to advance the field by integrating emerging technologies in the logistics industry into academic curricula. Members agreed upon the establishment of four workgroups (Executive, Curriculum, Partnerships, Workforce), each with its own goals and comprised of members from both education and industry.   

Over the course of the project, Oakton hosted professional development workshops for high school and college faculty to provide community college and high school educators with industry-endorsed content and resources that they can incorporate into their courses. Workshop topics included an introduction to the Tableau data management software that helps students learn how to visualize and tell a story about the data and the SCM Globe simulator which provides animated map-based simulations to teach principles of supply chain management and distribution. Participants were also provided with the content they could use to teach an introduction to Radio Frequency Identification as well as the Emaint computerized maintenance management software which can centralize maintenance information, facilitate processes, and automate tasks to improve efficiency. 

Sinclair developed processes for Prior Learning Assessment (PLA) including the Process for Proficiency Exams and the Process for Articulated Credit to help both students and faculty better understand the steps necessary to attain PLA credit. The Military Transfer Assurance Guides (MTAG) have also been updated to show Sinclair course alignments with Current Ohio Statewide Course/Program Equivalency Guarantees which will ensure that students entering Sinclair with military experience/education can participate in statewide course equivalencies. Although specific to the state of Ohio, many other states have a similar program, Sinclair's use of the MTAG can provide a model for those processes.  


Last Modified: 11/28/2022
Modified by: Robert W Sompolski
